subject: RE: [junit] RE: [java-gui-testing] test-running extensions, was: JUnit extra
msgSnippet: You are right, I m sorry. From the other point of view - I still have javac somewhere on my harddrive, what else I need? :-) Default interface (default means
messageBody:
You are right, I'm sorry.

From the other point of view - I still have javac somewhere on my
harddrive, what else I need? :-)

Default interface (default means that is comes with framework)
<code>TestListener</code> and class <code>TestReslut</code> that can
notify TestListeners I think is the "open listener architecture" that
you are talking about. I don't see any benefits of using junit-addons
for that particular task, it is all there, in junit.jar.



Dennis.



-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Monday, August 25, 2003 1:07 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] RE: [java-gui-testing] test-running extensions,
was: JUnit extra



Dennis N. Stetsenko wrote:

> Tom,
>
> junit-addon was the first tool I've take a look at. Unfortunately it
is
> not even close to the task I'm solving.

That's surprising, since it gives you an open listener architecture. You

can do anything with it. What do you need that it doesn't support?

I admit that a custom <junit> formatter is a good solution, but please
be careful about saying in public that a tool is "not even close" when
the pieces are all there. :)
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
